description: From Middle English, from Old French, from Latin īnsolēns (“unaccustomed, unwanted, unusual, immoderate, excessive, arrogant, insolent”), from in- (privative prefix) + solēns, present participle of solere (“to be accustomed, to be wont”).

adjectives.description: insolent (comparative more insolent, superlative most insolent)

entries.meaning: Insulting in manner or words, particularly in an arrogant or insubordinate manner.

examples: Diogenes Laertius reports that Diogenes was apt to take the identification with the dog at face value, as when he lifted his leg and relieved himself on a group of young insolents who teased him with a dog's bone  […]
